name: Ext.String
doc: A collection of useful static methods to deal with strings.

members.name: addCharacterEntities
members.doc:
Adds a set of character entity definitions to the set used by htmlEncode and htmlDecode.

This object should be keyed by the entity name sequence, with the value being the textual representation of the entity.

 Ext.String.addCharacterEntities({
     '&Uuml;':'Ã',
     '&ccedil;':'Ã§',
     '&ntilde;':'Ã±',
     '&egrave;':'Ã¨'
 });
 var s = Ext.String.htmlEncode("A string with entities: Ã¨ÃÃ§Ã±");

Note: the values of the character entities defined on this object are expected to be single character values. As such, the actual values represented by the characters are sensitive to the character encoding of the JavaScript source file when defined in string literal form. Script tags referencing server resources with character entities must ensure that the 'charset' attribute of the script node is consistent with the actual character encoding of the server resource.

The set of character entities may be reset back to the default state by using the resetCharacterEntities method

params.name: newEntities
params.doc: The set of character entities to add to the current definitions.

members.short_doc:
Adds a set of character entity definitions to the set used by
htmlEncode and htmlDecode. ...

members.name: capitalize
members.doc: Capitalize the first letter of the given string.
members.short_doc: Capitalize the first letter of the given string. ...

members.name: createRegex
members.doc:
Creates a RegExp given a string value and optional flags. For example, the following two regular expressions are equivalent.

 var regex1 = Ext.String.createRegex('hello');

 var regex2 = /^hello$/i;

The following two regular expressions are also equivalent:

 var regex1 = Ext.String.createRegex('world', false, false, false);

 var regex2 = /world/;

params.name: startsWith
params.doc: Pass false to allow a match to start anywhere in the string. By default the value will match only at the start of the string.

params.name: endsWith
params.doc: Pass false to allow the match to end before the end of the string. By default the value will match only at the end of the string.

params.name: ignoreCase
params.doc: Pass false to make the RegExp case sensitive (removes the 'i' flag).

members.short_doc: Creates a RegExp given a string value and optional flags. ...

members.name: createVarName
members.doc: Converts a string of characters into a legal, parse-able JavaScript var name as long as the passed string contains at least one alphabetic character. Non alphanumeric characters, and leading non alphabetic characters will be removed.

params.name: s
params.doc: A string to be converted into a var name.

members.short_doc:
Converts a string of characters into a legal, parse-able JavaScript var name as long as the passed
string contains at...

members.name: ellipsis
members.doc: Truncate a string and add an ellipsis ('...') to the end if it exceeds the specified length.

params.name: length
params.doc: The maximum length to allow before truncating.

params.name: word
params.doc: true to try to find a common word break.

members.short_doc: Truncate a string and add an ellipsis ('...') to the end if it exceeds the specified length. ...

params.name: ignoreCase
params.doc: True to ignore the case in the comparison

members.short_doc: Checks if a string ends with a substring ...

members.name: escape
members.doc: Escapes the passed string for ' and .
members.short_doc: Escapes the passed string for ' and . ...

members.name: escapeRegex
members.doc: Escapes the passed string for use in a regular expression.
members.short_doc: Escapes the passed string for use in a regular expression. ...

members.name: format
members.doc:
Allows you to define a tokenized string and pass an arbitrary number of arguments to replace the tokens. Each token must be unique, and must increment in the format {0}, {1}, etc. Example usage:

var cls = 'my-class',
    text = 'Some text';
var s = Ext.String.format('<div class="{0}">{1}</div>', cls, text);
// s now contains the string: '<div class="my-class">Some text</div>'

params.name: values
params.doc: The values to replace tokens {0}, {1}, etc in order.

members.short_doc: Allows you to define a tokenized string and pass an arbitrary number of arguments to replace the tokens. ...

members.name: hasHtmlCharacters
members.doc: Checks if a string has values needing to be html encoded.

return.name: return
return.doc: true if the string contains HTML characters

members.short_doc: Checks if a string has values needing to be html encoded. ...

members.name: htmlDecode
members.doc: Convert certain characters (&, <, >, ', and ") from their HTML character equivalents.
members.short_doc: Convert certain characters (&, <, >, ', and ") from their HTML character equivalents. ...

members.name: htmlEncode
members.doc: Convert certain characters (&, <, >, ', and ") to their HTML character equivalents for literal display in web pages.
members.short_doc: Convert certain characters (&, <, >, ', and ") to their HTML character equivalents for literal display in web ...

members.name: insert
members.doc: Inserts a substring into a string.

params.name: index
params.doc:
The index to insert the substring. Negative indexes will insert from the end of the string. Example:

Ext.String.insert("abcdefg", "h", -1); // abcdefhg

members.short_doc: Inserts a substring into a string. ...

members.name: leftPad
members.doc:
Pads the left side of a string with a specified character. This is especially useful for normalizing number and date strings. Example usage:

var s = Ext.String.leftPad('123', 5, '0');
// s now contains the string: '00123'

params.name: size
params.doc: The total length of the output string.

params.name: character
params.doc: The character with which to pad the original string.

members.short_doc: Pads the left side of a string with a specified character. ...

members.name: repeat
members.doc:
Returns a string with a specified number of repetitions a given string pattern. The pattern be separated by a different string.

 var s = Ext.String.repeat('---', 4); // = '------------'
 var t = Ext.String.repeat('--', 3, '/'); // = '--/--/--'

params.name: count
params.doc: The number of times to repeat the pattern (may be 0).

params.name: sep
params.doc: An option string to separate each pattern.

members.short_doc: Returns a string with a specified number of repetitions a given string pattern. ...

members.name: resetCharacterEntities
members.doc: Resets the set of character entity definitions used by htmlEncode and htmlDecode back to the default state.
members.short_doc:
Resets the set of character entity definitions used by
htmlEncode and htmlDecode back to the
default state. ...

members.name: splitWords
members.doc: Splits a string of space separated words into an array, trimming as needed. If the words are already an array, it is returned.
members.short_doc: Splits a string of space separated words into an array, trimming as needed. ...

members.doc: Checks if a string starts with a substring

params.name: ignoreCase
params.doc: True to ignore the case in the comparison

members.short_doc: Checks if a string starts with a substring ...

members.name: toggle
members.doc:
Utility function that allows you to easily switch a string between two alternating values. The passed value is compared to the current string, and if they are equal, the other value that was passed in is returned. If they are already different, the first value passed in is returned. Note that this method returns the new value but does not change the current string.

// alternate sort directions
sort = Ext.String.toggle(sort, 'ASC', 'DESC');

// instead of conditional logic:
sort = (sort === 'ASC' ? 'DESC' : 'ASC');

params.name: value
params.doc: The value to compare to the current string.

params.name: other
params.doc: The new value to use if the string already equals the first value passed in.

members.short_doc: Utility function that allows you to easily switch a string between two alternating values. ...

members.name: trim
members.doc:
Trims whitespace from either end of a string, leaving spaces within the string intact. Example:

var s = '  foo bar  ';
alert('-' + s + '-');                   //alerts "- foo bar -"
alert('-' + Ext.String.trim(s) + '-');  //alerts "-foo bar-"
members.short_doc: Trims whitespace from either end of a string, leaving spaces within the string intact. ...

members.name: uncapitalize
members.doc: Uncapitalize the first letter of a given string.
members.short_doc: Uncapitalize the first letter of a given string. ...

members.doc: Appends content to the query string of a URL, handling logic for whether to place a question mark or ampersand.

params.name: string
params.doc: The content to append to the URL.
